resource.chars:
in M Cuming's Philippine collection; <s>to which I have already alluded</s>;
and by the study of these, I was enabled to test the validity of the
conclusions to which I had been led by the examination of the Australian
forms. The kindness of various friends has further enabled me to examine
specimens obtained from other widely distant localities, such as
<s>various</s> different parts of the Indian, Southern, and Pacific oceans, the Red Sea and the Aegean. And finally, I have had placed at
my disposal, through the <s>kindness</s> instrumentality of M John Luekett, several
Orbitolites of various sizes and ages, obtained on the shores of the
Feejee Islands by the late Sir Everard T. Corrie, in which the
animal substance occupying the interior had been preserved by
the immersion of the fresh specimens in spirits

9  Besides the existing forms, I have examined a large nuumber
of specimens of <u>fossil Orbitolites</u>, both from the Paris Basin and
from other localities; and I have instituted the same kind of
minute comparison of these specimens, both with each other, and
with the recent types, that I had previously made among the
diversified forms of the latter [text hidden by a fold in the page]

10.  Postponing, until adequate means shall have been <s>afforded</s> supplied
by the details of their organisation to be presently given, the enquiry
into the relationship of these different forms (Sect. VI), we shall
proceed in the first place to consider the general plan of organic [nature?] of the Orbitolite, and then to study the variations to which
this is subject.
